r.description: real interest rate on domestic debt

rextg.description: real interest rate on public commercial debt

rstar.description: real interest rate on private commercial debt

10.description: marginal product of capital in tradable sector

11.description: constant elasticity of substitution consumption basket

14.latex: P_{t}{b^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{t}-{b^{\mathfrak{s}\ast}}_{t} = r_{x,t} {k^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{x,t-1} + r_{n,t-1} {k^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{n,t-1} + w_{t}L_{t}^{\mathfrak{s}}+ \frac{\mathcal{R}_{t}}{1+a} +\frac{\mathcal{T}_{t}}{1+a}-\frac{1+{r^{\ast}}_{t-1}}{1+g} {b^{\mathfrak{s}\ast}}_{t-1} \\ +\frac{1+r_{t-1}}{1+g} P_{t} {b^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{t-1} - P_{k,t}\left( {i^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{x,t} +{i^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{n,t} + {AC^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{x,t} + {AC^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{n,t}\right) - P_{t}{c^{\mathfrak{s}}_{t}}(1+h_{t})-\mu {z^{e}}_{t-1}-\mathcal{P^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{t} - {\Phi^{\mathfrak{s}}}_{t}

19.description: household (savers) first-order condition (modified consumption Euler equation)

20.description: household (savers) first-order condition (equalizes real interest rate on domestic bonds and foreign private bonds)

21.description: household (savers) first-order condition (equalizes return on capital in tradable sector with real interest rate)

22.description: household (savers) first-order condition (equalizes return on capital in non-tradable sector with real interest rate)

25.description: real interest rate on private external debt

28.description: conversion of public capital into effective public capital

31.description: real interest rate on public external debt

32.description: cost overruns from absorptive capacity constraints

44.description: sum of budget constraints (net foreign debt equals national spending less national income)

7.description: marginal product of labor in non-tradable sector

8.description: marginal product of labor in tradable sector

9.description: marginal product of capital in non-tradable sector

description: Debt Investment Growth Model based on Buffie et al. (2012)
name: Debt Investment Growth Model 2

VA_n.notes: This is used to pin down the distribution of imports, tradables, and non-tradables in the economy. (not in the paper)

a_ratio.description: ratio of labor supply of non-savers to labor supply of savers
a_ratio.notes: We set this ratio to 1.5, so 60% percent of the consumers are non-savers. This is broadly in line with survey findings in LICs.

alpha_k.description: cost share of non-traded inputs in the production of private capital
alpha_k.notes: Data on the ratio of imported machinery and equipment to aggregate investment indicate that the cost share parameters are around 0.5 in SSA. One-half is also the guesstimate used by the IMF (2007a) in its analysis of scaling up public investment in Nigeria.

alpha_n.description: capital’s share in value added in the non-traded sector
alpha_n.notes: Data on factor shares may be found in social accounting matrices assembled by the Global Trade Analysis Project (GTAP) and the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI). The GTAP5 database for SSA suggests a capital share of 55 - 60% in the non-tradables sector and 35 - 40% in the tradables sector. The data in Thurlow et al. (2004) and Perrault et al. (2010) suggest similar numbers. Accordingly, we set the parameter to 0.55 in the non-traded sector and 0.40 in the traded sector.

alpha_x.description: capital’s share in value added in the traded sector
alpha_x.notes: Data on factor shares may be found in social accounting matrices assembled by the Global Trade Analysis Project (GTAP) and the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI). The GTAP5 database for SSA suggests a capital share of 55 - 60% in the non-tradables sector and 35 - 40% in the tradables sector. The data in Thurlow et al. (2004) and Perrault et al. (2010) suggest similar numbers. Accordingly, we set the parameter to 0.55 in the non-traded sector and 0.40 in the traded sector.

alpha_z.description: cost share of non-traded inputs in the production of public capital
alpha_z.notes: Data on the ratio of imported machinery and equipment to aggregate investment indicate that the cost share parameters are around 0.5 in SSA. One-half is also the guesstimate used by the IMF (2007a) in its analysis of scaling up public investment in Nigeria.

delta_n.description: depreciation rate of non-traded capital inputs
delta_n.notes: There is little hard data on depreciation rates in LICs. Our choice of 5% is in line with estimates for developed countries.

delta_x.description: depreciation rate of traded capital inputs
delta_x.notes: There is little hard data on depreciation rates in LICs. Our choice of 5% is in line with estimates for developed countries.

delta_z.description: depreciation rate of public capital inputs
delta_z.notes: There is little hard data on depreciation rates in LICs. Our choice of 5% is in line with estimates for developed countries.

epsilon.description: intratemporal elasticity of substitution across goods
epsilon.notes: We fix the elasticity of substitution in comsumption at 0.50 as estimates of compensated elasticities of demand tend to be small at high levels of aggregation, especially when food claims a large share of total consumption.

eta.notes: The portfolio adjustment cost parameter controls the degree of openness of the capital account. We set it equal to 1 in the base case to capture the fact that the private sector has limited access to international capital markets. We assume that the public risk premium is constant and set equal to zero.

etag.notes: The portfolio adjustment cost parameter controls the degree of openness of the capital account. We set it equal to 1 in the base case to capture the fact that the private sector has limited access to international capital markets. We assume that the public risk premium is constant and set equal to zero.

fo.description: fraction of recurrent costs to user fees for infrastructure
fo.notes: The user fee for infrastructure services is a fixed multiple/fraction of recurrent costs. Fuel taxes, which are earmarked for road maintenance and construction, electricity tariffs, and user charges for water and sanitation are low but not trivial in LICs. According to Briceño-Garmendia et al. (2008), on average, user fees recoup 50% of recurrent costs in SSA. Again, however, there is considerable variation -- Zambia’s average electricity tariff was three cents per kWH in 2008. We decided therefore to let this share vary from 0.20 to unity, setting it to 0.5 in the base case.

g.notes: The trend growth rate of 1.5% equals the 1990-2008 per capita growth rate for SSA reported in African Development Indicators.

imp2gdp.notes: This is used to pin down the distribution of imports, tradables, and non-tradables in the economy. (not in the paper)

lambda1.description: speed of reaction of tax adjustment

lambda2.description: speed of reaction of debt adjustment

lambda3.description: speed of reaction of transfer adjustment

lambda4.description: speed of reaction of debt adjustment

nxpsi.notes: The ratio of sectoral output elasticities is set independently. This ratio and other values assigned elsewhere in calibrating the model -- most notably, the return on infrastructure -- pin down sectoral output elasticity in each sector. We assume that the ratio of elasticities is equal to 1 in all runs.

omega.description: elasticity of investment with respect to Tobin's q
omega.notes: This parameters is the elasticity of investment with respect to Tobin’s q. There are no reliable estimates of this elasticity for LICs. The assigned value, 2, is at the high end of estimates for developed countries. The results do not change substantively when it equals 1 or 10.

phi.notes: The base case assumes that investment is somewhat effcient (parameters set to 0.6) and that scaling up does not strain absorptive capacity (capacity constrant set to zero). Motivated by the findings in Hulten (1996), Pritchett (2000), and Foster and Briceño-Garmendia (2010), we also investigate scenarios in which the scaling up is associated with extreme ineffciency (parameter set to 0.2) and a tight absorptive capacity constraint (parameter set to 5).

rstar.notes: We fix the risk-free foreign real interest rate at 4%, the approximate average of the historical real returns on stocks and 3-10 year T-bills in the United States.

s.notes: The base case assumes that investment is somewhat effcient (parameters set to 0.6) and that scaling up does not strain absorptive capacity (capacity constrant set to zero). Motivated by the findings in Hulten (1996), Pritchett (2000), and Foster and Briceño-Garmendia (2010), we also investigate scenarios in which the scaling up is associated with extreme ineffciency (parameter set to 0.2) and a tight absorptive capacity constraint (parameter set to 5).

s_s.description: steady state efficiency of public investment
s_s.notes: The base case assumes that investment is somewhat effcient (parameters set to 0.6) and that scaling up does not strain absorptive capacity (capacity constrant set to zero). Motivated by the findings in Hulten (1996), Pritchett (2000), and Foster and Briceño-Garmendia (2010), we also investigate scenarios in which the scaling up is associated with extreme ineffciency (parameter set to 0.2) and a tight absorptive capacity constraint (parameter set to 5).

sigma_n.notes: The base case does not incorporate learning externalities. In alternative runs that allow for learning effects, the output learning externalities are set to 0.08 so that the social return to capital in the traded sector is about 30% higher than the private return.

sigma_x.notes: The base case does not incorporate learning externalities. In alternative runs that allow for learning effects, the output learning externalities are set to 0.08 so that the social return to capital in the traded sector is about 30% higher than the private return.

tau.notes: According to Agenor and Montiel (1999), most estimates of this parameter for LDCs lie between 0.10 and 0.50. The value in the base case, 0.34, equals the average estimate for LICs in Ogaki et al. (1996).

xi_n.notes: The base case does not incorporate learning externalities. In alternative runs that allow for learning effects, the output learning externalities are set to 0.08 so that the social return to capital in the traded sector is about 30% higher than the private return.

xi_x.notes: The base case does not incorporate learning externalities. In alternative runs that allow for learning effects, the output learning externalities are set to 0.08 so that the social return to capital in the traded sector is about 30% higher than the private return.

itermax.description: Determines the maximum number of iterations used in the non-linear solver.
itermax.notes: The maxit option is shared with the  steady command. So a change in maxit in a simul command will also be considered in the following steady commands. [NB: for advanced users only]

R_zo.notes: Estimates of the return on infrastructure are all over the map but the weight of the evidence in both micro and macro studies points to a high average return. The median rate of return on World Bank projects circa 2001 was 20% in SSA and 15-29% for various sub-categories of infrastructure investment. Foster and Briceño-Garmendia (2010) estimate returns for electricity water and sanitation irrigation and roads range from 17% to 24%. Similarly the macro-based estimates in Dalgaard and Hansen (2005) cluster between 15% and 30% for a wide array of different estimators. Hulten et al. (2006) Escribano et al. (2008) Calderón et al. (2009) and Calderón and Servén (2010) supply additional evidence of high returns. All of this adds up to a presumption that high returns are the norm. We consider a high-return scenario as the base case by setting the return on infrastructure to 0.25 at the initial steady state.

ho.notes: The consumption VAT in the model proxies for the average indirect tax rate. Our rate is 15% at the initial steady state. This is comparable to the average VAT of LICs which using 2005-06 data by the International Bureau of Fiscal Documentation is estimated to be close to 15.8%.

izy.notes: We set the initial infrastructure investment to be equal to 6% of GDP. This initial figure includes the net investment associated with trend growth and the outlays on operations and maintenance (O+M) which average about 3.4% of GDP for LICs in SSA. This figure is close to the average for LICs in SSA which in 2008 corresponded to 6.09% as suggested by Briceño-Garmendia et al. (2008)

oilro.notes: For the base case remittances and grants are assumed to be 5% and 4% of GDP at their initial equilibrium respectively. These are in line with averages for LICs in the last decade. For the baseline calibration we assume that the economy is not endowed with natural resources.

r_dco.description: initial real interest rate on public commercial loans
r_dco.notes: Ghana paid 8.7% on the $750 mn. Eurobond it floated in 2007. This is slightly above Gueye and Sy’s (2010) estimate of the average interest rate SSA pays (8.55%) on debt raised in external capital markets excluding Seychelles and South Africa. The IMF-WB’s DSAs show an average interest rate of 2.3% on concessional loans taken out by LICs in 2009-2010. Assuming 2.5% inflation in world prices of traded goods the corresponding (initial) real rates in dollars are about 6% for commercial debt and 0% for concessional debt. The latter is assumed to be constant through the analysis.

ro.description: initial real interest rate on domestic loans
ro.notes: Real interest rate on domestic debt should match country-specific data.

share_b.notes: Different datasets give different numbers for the ratio of domestic debt to GDP in LICs. We settled on 20% by averaging the figures reported in IMF (2009a) Panizza (2008) and Arnone and Presbitero (2010).

share_bstar.notes: We set concessional external debt equal to 50% of GDP at the initial equilibrium given that the ratio of total public debt to GDP and the share of concessional loans in total debt were about 70% and 69% respectively for LICs during 2007-2008. As little is known about the likely value of private foreign debt (or assets) in LICs we set this ratio to zero for the base case. We also assume that initially the economy has no access to external commercial loans implying that this value is zero as well.

share_d.notes: We set concessional external debt equal to 50% of GDP at the initial equilibrium given that the ratio of total public debt to GDP and the share of concessional loans in total debt were about 70% and 69% respectively for LICs during 2007-2008. As little is known about the likely value of private foreign debt (or assets) in LICs we set this ratio to zero for the base case. We also assume that initially the economy has no access to external commercial loans implying that this value is zero as well.

share_dc.description: initial public external commercial debt-to-gdp ratio
share_dc.notes: We set concessional external debt equal to 50% of GDP at the initial equilibrium given that the ratio of total public debt to GDP and the share of concessional loans in total debt were about 70% and 69% respectively for LICs during 2007-2008. As little is known about the likely value of private foreign debt (or assets) in LICs we set this ratio to zero for the base case. We also assume that initially the economy has no access to external commercial loans implying that this value is zero as well.

share_grants.notes: For the base case remittances and grants are assumed to be 5% and 4% of GDP at their initial equilibrium respectively. These are in line with averages for LICs in the last decade. For the baseline calibration we assume that the economy is not endowed with natural resources.

share_remit.notes: For the base case remittances and grants are assumed to be 5% and 4% of GDP at their initial equilibrium respectively. These are in line with averages for LICs in the last decade. For the baseline calibration we assume that the economy is not endowed with natural resources.
